answers.answer: Wouldn't abnormally high insulin levels be a better indication of insulin resistance? than what?Is it that tuff make a change that will save your life.

Well people get other health issues as they get older, that might make it harder for them to start an exercise program.But also seems like if blood glucose is the standard test, by the time a problem is detected some damage is already done. Some of the insulin producing cells have stopped functioning forever. Even with the lifestyle change you will not get them back to 100%.Wouldn't it be better to diagnose before this happens?

That would require testing every one for c-peptide. there is no test for insulin however when the pancreas makes insulin it is attached to a c-peptide that gets stripped off later. so the test is for c-peptides. an expensive test to give to millions of people that have no problem and will develop no problem.  and will have to be repeated every couple of years.

Well if its just a question of money then still sounds like a good investment to me.Even if only a small amount of people can live healthier lives as a result.I wish I was educated about this test before. Will definitely pass it on, thanks!

the test wont tell you that in 10 or 20 years youl be diabetic it might tell you that in 2 years or 3 years you will be.  So you will be 37 instead of 40 when find out you have to make life style changes.

Then I am missing something. According to all the articles initially when your insulin resistance rises you body overcompensates by producing more insulin, so wouldn't that be a good point to start diagnosing?

We are not talking about some rare disease here that affects 1 in 1000.According to statistics 90 million are diagnosed with per-diabetes in the US, thats almost 1 in 4. And I bet if you look at 45+ age group the ratio is probably much worse.So given the statistics I find it suprizing that no efforts are made towards earlier diagnosis.

question: Wouldn't abnormally high insulin levels be a better indication of insulin resistance?In which case diagnosis can be made a lot earlier? Like maybe when a person is still young and can make lifestyle changes easier than when they are  already in their late 40s?
title: Why test for blood glucose and not insulin?
